arguments.query: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 4 service of process

messages.content:
### Search Result (Westlaw)

**Rule 4. Summons.**

> **(a) Service of a Summons.**
> 
> (1) **By Individual Delivery.**
> 
> (A) To an individual—personal delivery.
> 
> (B) To a corporation, partnership, or association—delivery to an officer, director, or managing agent.
> 
> (2) **By Mail.**
> 
> (A) To an individual—service by first-class mail, postage prepaid, with a notice of receipt.
> 
> (B) To a corporation, partnership, or association—service by first-class mail, postage prepaid, to the corporation’s registered agent.
> 
> **(b) Proof of Service.**
> 
> (1) Proof of service shall be filed with the clerk of the court.
> 
> (2) A declaration of service shall include the date, time, and manner of service, and the name of the person served.
> 
> **Citation:** Fed. R. Civ. P. 4 (2024).

*Source: Westlaw, Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 4, latest edition.*

The plaintiff alleges that the summons was properly served on the defendant in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The pivotal question is whether the method of service satisfies Rule 4.

> **Rule 4. Summons.**
>

> 
> (2) **By Mail.**
> 
> (A) To an individual—service by first‑class mail, postage prepaid, with a notice of receipt.
> 
> (B) To a corporation, partnership, or association—service by first‑class mail, postage prepaid, to the corporation’s registered agent.
> 
> (b) **Proof of Service.**
> 
> (1) Proof of service shall be filed with the clerk of the court.
> 
> (2) A declaration of service shall include the date, time, and manner of service, and the name of the person served.
> 
> **Citation:** Fed. R. Civ. P. 4 (2024).

Accordingly, the brief relies on Fed. R. Civ. P. 4 (2024) as the controlling authority.
